text.author: Ronald Reagan
text.sourcePublication: John Woolley and Gerhard Peters, The American Presidency Project
text.title: Inaugural Adress Ronald Reagan
text.summary1: (human1) In his inaugural address, US President Ronald Reagan praises the peaceful transition of power to a new Presidency and lays out his plans to reduce the role of government and spending in order to revive the economy and combat inflation and unemployment.
text.summary2: (human2) In a speech addressing the US, Ronald Reagan praises the tradition of the transfer of authority, before speaking about the economic trouble confronting the nation, blaming the tax system and high public spending, before naming the government as the problem and calling on all Americans to bear the burden of the solution by putting in the work to revive the economy.
text.summary3: (human3) US President Ronald Reagan gives his inauguration speech, in which he praises the democratic process of the transfer of power, acknowledges the economic affliction the country faces (namely, unemployment and substantial taxation), and shares his concern for special interest groups and equal opportunities for all Americans.
text.summary4: (human4) Ronald Reagan addresses and celebrates the orderly transfer of authority and thanks the current President for carrying the tradition forward, before decrying deficit spending, inflation, and runaway living costs, emphasizing that all Americans, regardless of any divisions, should be provided with equal economic opportunities.
text.summary5: (human5) In his inaugural speech, Ronald Reagan reflects on U.S. economic issues of inflation and national debt and urges a collective attempt to end inequities towards the working class, ideally resulting in a revived economy.
